question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
Let

\[S = \left\{[x_1, x_2, x_3]^T:\, x_1 + x_2 + x_3 = 0\right\}\]

be the subspace of vectors in $\mathbb R^3$ whose components sum to
zero.

\textbf{(b)} Write down a basis for \emph{S}.
sols:
If \emph{S} is the null space of the matrix \emph{A} from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2012/Question_03_(a)}{part
(a)}, then the basis for \emph{S} can be found as the basis of
\emph{N(A)}. Let's choose the simplest form $A= \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}.$

We see that we choose \emph{x\textsubscript{2}} and
\emph{x\textsubscript{3}} to be free variables when we set
\emph{x\textsubscript{1} = -x\textsubscript{2}-x\textsubscript{3}}. That
is, the kernel \emph{N(A)} (and with it the subspace \emph{S}) can be
expressed as

\[\begin{bmatrix}
x_{1}\\
x_{2}\\
x_{3}
\end{bmatrix} = x_{2}\begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix} + x_{3}\begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\]

In other words, a basis for \emph{S} is given by the two vectors

\[b_{1} = \begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}, \quad b_{2} = \begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\]

The dimension of \emph{S} is 2, because if we fix two of
\emph{x\textsubscript{1}}, \emph{x\textsubscript{2}},
\emph{x\textsubscript{3}} we can always choose the remaining such that
the equation \emph{x\textsubscript{1} + x\textsubscript{2} +
x\textsubscript{3} = 0} is satisfied. So let us choose
\emph{x\textsubscript{2} = r} and \emph{x\textsubscript{3} = s}. Then
\emph{x\textsubscript{1} = -x\textsubscript{2}-x\textsubscript{3}=-r-s}.
That is, \emph{S} can be expressed as all vectors of the form
$\begin{bmatrix} -r-s \\ r \\ s\end{bmatrix} = r\begin{bmatrix}-1 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} + s\begin{bmatrix}-1 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{bmatrix}$.
In other words, a basis for \emph{S} is given by the vectors
$b_{1} = \begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}, \quad b_{2} = \begin{bmatrix}
-1\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}$
hints:
Use the matrix \emph{A} from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2012/Question_03_(a)}{part
(a)} and calculate its kernel as usual.

For an alternative solution, what is the dimension (number of free
variables) of \emph{S}? Fix the free variable(s) and express the
remaining variable(s) in terms of those.
